item.name: Comment
item.text:
short and sweet
Constraining the behavior of Nostalgic to only swell if notes are held longer than 150ms gives more power to the player to set off Nostalgic swells in a controlled manner.
I like playing staccato arpeggios and then holding certain notes down longer so that they pop out in the nostalgic swells.

item.name: Comment
item.text: This gallery was made by Mike Mulshine for bitKlavier, specifically focusing on new constraints features.

item.name: Comment
item.text:
dots and constellations
Melodies set the tempo. Chords set off Synchronic pulses.
I like to play scales and arpeggios mixed in with block chord accents. The scales and arpeggios set the tempo of synchronic pulses that are triggered by the chords.

item.name: Comment
item.text:
production punch
An example of how to use envelope features to reshape your sound.
This one gives whatever samples you are using a little extra punch!

item.name: Comment
item.text:
pairs and pears
Setting the cluster threshold very low (< 30 ms) and cluster min/max both to 2 isolates block dyads for all synchronic behavior.
In this piano, block dyads have a cascading effect. Notably, nothing else does!

item.name: Comment
item.text:
play stuff delay stuff
Dyads, triads, 4-note chords, 5-note chords, and 6+ note chords all pulsate at different rates relative to the same tempo. Creates a nice variable delay effect, as well as a chance to play with polyrhythms.

item.name: Comment
item.text:
history repeats
Now that a Synchronic preparation can play more than one set of Synchronic pulses at a time (as set by num clusters), you can start Synchronic pulses without interrupting previous pulses. This can result in a natural sounding delay/decay effect.
Play chords at different rates against the ostinato of the pulses to create complex textures. Play a melody overtop!

item.name: Comment
item.text:
limits break limits
Another Nostalgic-focused piano tailored for improvisation. It focuses on hold time constraints. Notes held shorter than 200ms do not swell. Notes held between 200 and 500ms swell an octave above. Notes held greater than 500ms swell an octave below.
Creating limits expands the sonic landscape as well as the musician's vocabulary.
